title: 108_hr4019
content: Taiwan's participation in the World Health Organization is addressed in Section 1. Taiwan's substantial achievements in health include high life expectancy levels and low maternal and infant mortality rates, making access to international health cooperation crucial for public health improvement. Taiwan has achieved high life expectancy and low maternal and infant mortality rates, comparable to western countries. They have collaborated closely with the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention on public health issues and have shown willingness to assist in international aid efforts. In response to an earthquake in El Salvador, Taiwan sent rescue teams and donated relief aid. Taiwan has collaborated with the US on public health issues and international aid efforts. The Taiwanese Ministry of Foreign Affairs donated $200,000 in relief aid to El Salvador. The World Health Assembly allowed observers like the Palestine Liberation Organization and the Holy See to participate in its activities. The US declared support for Taiwan's participation in international organizations. Public Law 106-137 required a report on efforts to support Taiwan's participation in the WHO. President Bush expressed support for Taiwan's meaningful participation in the WHO in 2001. President Bush and Secretary of Health and Human Services Tommy Thompson expressed support for Taiwan's participation in the WHO, emphasizing the importance of Taiwan's voice being heard in international organizations and its efforts to achieve the same level of public health as other nations. Taiwan donated $1,000,000 to the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis, and Malaria in 2002. In 2003, Taiwan experienced 84 deaths from SARS. Avian influenza has resurfaced in Asia, emphasizing the importance of global health cooperation. The text chunk discusses the importance of allowing all people, including those from Taiwan, access to international health organizations like the WHO. It proposes a plan for the Secretary of State to endorse Taiwan for observer status at the World Health Assembly in Geneva. The Secretary of State is required to submit a report to Congress detailing efforts to endorse Taiwan for observer status at the World Health Assembly in Geneva. The report must include steps taken to promote Taiwan's bid and obtain observer status at the annual summit. The House of Representatives passed the bill on April 21, 2004.
